thread.title: Jeremy Corbyn ridiculed by MPs after celebrating social media success over poor poll ratings
thread.title_full: Jeremy Corbyn ridiculed by MPs after celebrating social media success over poor poll ratings

author: Laura Hughes
title: Jeremy Corbyn ridiculed by MPs after celebrating social media success over poor poll ratings
text:
Jeremy Corbyn ridiculed by MPs after celebrating social media success over poor poll ratings Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn Credit: Leon Neal/Getty Images Laura Hughes , Political Correspondent 21 February 2017 • 7:38am 
J eremy Corbyn was ridiculed by his own MPs last night after he suggested that while Labour is down in the polls, it was winning on social media. 
The Labour leader said the patty was "better" at getting their message out online and blamed the media for the party's increasingly bad ratings. 
His comments came after an ICM poll for the Guardian showed the Conservatives extending their lead over Labour to 18 points, with the Tories on 44 per cent to Labour's 26 per cent. Watch | Jeremy Corbyn: Rumours of quitting are 'nonsense' 00:19 
M r Corbyn was confronted about the figures as he addressed the weekly meeting of the parliamentary Labour Party (PLP) last night. 
Chris Leslie, the former Shadow Chancellor, asked Mr Corbyn if he "had any comprehension" of what the figures meant for Labour's election chances. 
To which Mr Corbyn replied: "Of course I understand what's going on and the problems we have had in the media. I went to the #1daywithoutus lobby today to show my and Labour's support for rights of EU citizens living in the UK to stay after Brexit. — Jeremy Corbyn MP (@jeremycorbyn) February 20, 2017 Today I visited the @NewCharterGroup building site in #Ashton . Met with staff and spoke with them about importance of building council homes pic.twitter.com/LKYnsfrWFv — Jeremy Corbyn MP (@jeremycorbyn) February 9, 2017 
"We need to get a strong, positive message across and we do that better on social media." 
O ne Labour MP told The Times: "It's utter nonsense. It's worth sod all when it comes to being a parliamentary party and being able to shape and improve people's lives. 
"Pat yourselves on the back because you've got ten new followers this week? It's utter garbage." Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn Credit: Paul Grover for the Telegraph 
M r Corbyn also sought to rally the troops ahead of the by-elections in Stoke, where the party is attempting to see off the threat of Ukip leader Paul Nuttall, and Copeland, where the Tories are looking to win. 
"His message was that the by-elections are on a knife edge and that we need to fight for every vote and people need to support Labour's campaign in Stoke and Copeland," the source said. 
Adding that the Tories' lead in the polls will fall back when Brexit negotiations begin and they are "confronted by the reality" of the rest of the European Union briefing against the Government. Follow Telegraph News
